channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rishi Sunak Becomes the Front Runner for U.K. Prime Minister
item.description: Mr. Sunak’s warnings about inflation and his fiscal conservatism may have cost him the post in September. But now his accurate assessments are easing his path to Britain’s top job.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Hannah Mckay/Reuters
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak at a Conservative Party event in London in August.

item.title: Math Scores Fell in Nearly Every State, and Reading Dipped on National Exam
item.description: The results, from what is known as the nation’s report card, offer the most definitive picture yet of the pandemic’s devastating impact on students.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh and Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Not a single state was able to improve test scores for math.

item.title: Fears Over Fate of Democracy Leave Many Voters Frustrated and Resigned
item.description: As democracy frays around them, Republicans and Democrats see different culprits and different risks.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Liam James Doyle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Allyse Barba speaking with Mandela Barnes, the Democratic candidate for the Senate from Wisconsin, at an event in La Crosse. Ms. Barba does not believe voting will make a difference in Wisconsin.

item.title: Why Am I Seeing That Political Ad? Check Your ‘Trump Resistance’ Score.
item.description: To help campaigns target ads, voter-profiling firms score millions of Americans on issues like guns, vaccines and QAnon.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Tim Enthoven

item.title: Pelosi and Sanders Press Democrats’ Case, and More News From the Sunday Talk Shows
item.description: Democratic Party leaders turned toward inflation and the economy after a summer focus on abortion. Representative Nancy Mace, a Republican, said the G.O.P. would seek spending cuts.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont emphasized Social Security and Medicare as important voter issues in the primary elections.

item.title: Zeldin Agrees to Debate Hochul This Week in N.Y. Governor’s Race
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul and Representative Lee Zeldin will hold a single televised debate on Tuesday. Mr. Zeldin had long pushed for several debates.
item.dc:creator: Grace Ashford
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times, Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York, left, and Representative Lee Zeldin will hold a televised debate on Tuesday.

item.title: For Trump’s Backers in Congress, ‘Devil Terms’ Help Rally Voters
item.description: In vilifying tweets and speeches, G.O.P. lawmakers who contested the election have far outpaced other Republicans and Democrats in fueling polarization.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Valentino-DeVries and Steve Eder
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Xi Jinping Now Holds Near-Absolute Power in China, Creating Risks
item.description: Xi Jinping has created a new ruling elite packed with loyalist officials primed to elevate his agenda of bolstering national security and of turning China into a technological great power.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher and Chang Che
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping, left, with new members of the Politburo Standing Committee at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: China G.D.P. Data Is Unexpectedly Released After Delay
item.description: China said its output was up 3.9 percent from July through September, better than in the spring but still far short of Beijing’s target for the year.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Beijing vegetable market last month. China on Monday reported a modest rebound in economic activity for the quarter ending in September.

item.title: How Ukraine’s Army is Pioneering Anti-Drone Warfare
item.description: With an intense, hastily assembled effort, the Ukrainian military is pioneering successful techniques in the difficult art of anti-drone warfare.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Vadim Sarakhan/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers in Kyiv, Ukraine, trying to shoot down a drone during an attack on Oct. 17. The drone was believed to be an Iranian-made Shahed-136, purchased by Russia in August.

item.title: Trump Organization’s Tax Fraud Trial to Begin on Monday
item.description: The Trump Organization’s trial on tax fraud and other charges begins Monday in Manhattan, raising questions about the future of the former president’s family business.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jury selection in the trial of former president Donald J. Trump’s family begins on Monday.

item.title: ALCS: Yankees Season Ends as Astros Head to World Series
item.description: The gap between the American League’s two best teams proved awfully wide, with Houston heading to the World Series as the Yankees wonder what went wrong.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Houston Astros are the third team to sweep a division series and a league championship series in the same season. The others were the 2014 Kansas City Royal and the 2007 Colorado Rockies.

item.title: NLCS: Bryce Harper Leads Phillies to World Series
item.description: Harper’s two-run homer in the bottom of the eighth inning erased a one-run deficit and put Philadelphia back in the Fall Classic for the first time since 2009.
item.dc:creator: Scott Miller
item.media:credit: Eric Hartline/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Bryce Harper’s two-run home run in the eighth inning put Philadelphia ahead to stay in Game 5 of the National League Championship Series on Sunday.

item.title: Ralph Fiennes Is Playing Robert Moses in ‘Straight Line Crazy’
item.description: He’s playing New York’s own Caesar, Robert Moses, in a stage production at the Shed.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Erik Tanner for The New York Times

item.title: A ‘Tripledemic’? Flu and Other Infections Return as Covid Cases Rise
item.description: Flu cases are higher than usual for this time of year and are expected to soar in the coming weeks. A third virus, R.S.V., is straining pediatric hospitals in some states.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A young girl receiving a Covid test at Esperanza Health Center in Chicago in September.

item.title: Building Your Personal Brand Has Its Drawbacks. Burnout, for One.
item.description: Younger workers embraced the idea of a personal brand as a way to get ahead, and carve out some power and security in their careers. But posting through it has its drawbacks.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Eddie Guy

item.title: The New York State Sheep and Wool Festival Draws Younger Fans
item.description: The New York State Sheep and Wool Festival, long home to 4-H clubs and livestock hawkers, is drawing new attendees.
item.dc:creator: Rose Adams
item.media:credit: Mary Inhea Kang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sabrina Brokenborough wore head-to-ankle avant-garde knitwear of her own design to the New York State Sheep and Wool Festival.

item.title: The Way Los Angeles Is Trying to Solve Homelessness Is ‘Absolutely Insane’
item.description: Developing affordable housing projects shouldn’t make a miserable existence for those who’ve devoted their lives to it.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeremiah Dean, near an encampment in the parking lot where the Venice Dell Community project may be built in Los Angeles. Mr. Dean is homeless and has been living in a tent in the parking lot for more than three months.

item.title: For New York Governor, The Times Endorses Kathy Hochul
item.description: In-person voting begins on Oct. 29.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Jingyu Lin for The New York Times

item.title: Kari Ann Lake’s Hijacking of Martin Luther King
item.description: Like Donald Trump, she is invoking the civil rights icon in self-serving ways.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

item.title: Let’s Say Gay
item.description: “Queer” has begun to overtake other labels of sexuality. But what does it mean?
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul

item.title: Turns Out Sometimes the Government Can Get Things Right
item.description: We pay a lot of attention to government failures. But if we want better outcomes, we must celebrate and learn from the wins, too.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Herd and Donald P. Moynihan
item.media:credit: Pavel Popov

item.title: Reindeer Dog vs. the Swedish Tax Agency
item.description: Indigenous Sami tradition versus Swedish bureaucracy — who wins this dogfight?
item.dc:creator: Maria Fredriksson

item.title: Where Have All the Cèpes Gone?
item.description: This year, for the first time, I found only a few of these wild mushrooms.
item.dc:creator: Serge Schmemann
item.media:credit: Noah Kalina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mushroom hunts yielded mostly poisonous mushrooms this year, but none of the abundance of cèpes of better times.

item.title: No, Capitalism and the Internet Will Not Free China’s People
item.description: The Communist Party’s war on independent thought continues.
item.dc:creator: Ai Weiwei
item.media:credit: Elaine

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘How Yiyun Li Became a Beacon for Readers in Mourning’
item.description: The novelist Yiyun Li, known for her powerful distillations of personal grief, makes art from subverted expectations.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Kleeman, Jack D’Isidoro, Elisheba Ittoop, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Devin Murphy
item.media:credit: Naila Ruechel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yiyun Li at home in Princeton, New Jersey.

item.title: Your stories: Generational differences
item.description: We invited you to talk about your families and climate. Today, we’re sharing a few of the responses.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni

item.title: Encore: A Lifetime of Good Loving
item.description: After 56 years of marriage, a widow finds hope for the future by remembering the sweetness of life spent together.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Do You Have Messy Handwriting? We Want to See It.
item.description: Is your penmanship a mess? Can you often not read your own handwriting? Share something you wrote and later found hard to decipher.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Paoletto
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Blunder in Affirmative Action Case May Cost Harvard $15 Million
item.description: A missed insurance notice opened a window onto the cost of litigating challenges to race-conscious admissions programs to be heard this month by the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court will hear arguments in the affirmative action case involving Harvard on Oct. 31.

item.title: Roslyn Moves Inland and Breaks Up After Lashing Mexican Coast
item.description: The storm, which made landfall as a Category 3 hurricane, brought coastal flooding and dangerous winds to the country’s Pacific Coast, killing at least two people.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Alfredo Estrella/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hurricane Roslyn flooded streets in Puerto Vallarta, in Jalisco State in Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: Getting People Back on Trains, After the Pandemic Turned Many to Cars
item.description: While the federal government is committed to a multibillion-dollar improvement to train service, an already long schedule may face delays.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Carlos Osorio/Reuters
item.media:description: The federal government has said it is committed to a new passenger rail line through Ontario and Quebec.

item.title: Sex Discrimination Case in Hawaii Could Change High School Sports Across the U.S.
item.description: It is rare for Title IX cases to go to trial. In Hawaii, a looming case could be a landmark stress test for the 50-year-old law.
item.dc:creator: David W. Chen
item.media:credit: Marie Eriel Hobro for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashley Badis played water polo at James Campbell High School, but her team’s season was jeopardized because the school didn’t hire a coach. Her dad stepped in.

item.title: Work Burnout: How to Spot Symptoms and What to Do
item.description: Here’s how to recognize the physical symptoms of work-related stress — and what to do about them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Alva Skog

item.title: How to Break a Phone Addiction
item.description: Whether smartphone overuse constitutes a true addiction is still up for debate, but experts say there are ways to scale down.
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: How to Prevent Memory Loss
item.description: A new book by a renowned brain expert says there are a few simple things we can do to prevent memory decline as we age.
item.dc:creator: Hope Reese
item.category: The Complete Guide to Memory: The Science of Strengthening Your Mind (Book)
item.media:credit: Mikyung Lee

item.title: The Best Exercises to Prevent Lower Back Pain
item.description: Back pain is common and complicated. But altering your workout to build control and stability can help prevent it.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Cole Barash for The New York Times

item.title: What Are Your ‘Non-Negotiables’? Readers Share Wellness Rituals
item.description: Reading Nancy Drew. Watching the birds every day. Counting yellow doors. Thousands of Times readers shared their wellness “non-negotiables.”
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Andrea Chronopoulos
item.media:credit: Andrea Chronopoulos

item.title: ‘Back to the Future’ Musical to Open on Broadway Next Summer
item.description: The show, now in London, has a creative team that combines veterans of the film with some Broadway stalwarts. Performances will begin on June 30.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.category: Back to The Future: The Musical (Play)

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
